trans-unit.source: You can use SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) to administer Azure SQL Database logical servers and databases.
trans-unit.target: You can use SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) to administer Azure SQL Database logical servers and databases.

trans-unit.source: This topic walks you through common tasks with SSMS.
trans-unit.target: This topic walks you through common tasks with SSMS.

trans-unit.source: You should already have a logical server and database created in Azure SQL Database before you begin.
trans-unit.target: You should already have a logical server and database created in Azure SQL Database before you begin.

trans-unit.source: To get started, read <linkText>Create your first Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title> and then come back.
trans-unit.target: To get started, read <linkText>Create your first Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title> and then come back.

trans-unit.source: It's recommended that you use the latest version of SSMS whenever you work with Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: It's recommended that you use the latest version of SSMS whenever you work with Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Visit <linkText>Download SQL Server Management Studio</linkText><title></title> to get it.
trans-unit.target: Visit <linkText>Download SQL Server Management Studio</linkText><title></title> to get it.

trans-unit.source: Connecting to SQL Database requires that you know the server name on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Connecting to SQL Database requires that you know the server name on Azure.

trans-unit.source: You might need to sign in to the portal to get this information.
trans-unit.target: You might need to sign in to the portal to get this information.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: On the SQL Databases home page, click SERVERS at the top of the page to list all of the servers associated with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: On the SQL Databases home page, click SERVERS at the top of the page to list all of the servers associated with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Find the name of the server to which you want to connect and copy it to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Find the name of the server to which you want to connect and copy it to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure your SQL Database firewall to allow connections from your local machine.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure your SQL Database firewall to allow connections from your local machine.

trans-unit.source: You do this by adding your local machines IP address to the firewall exception list.
trans-unit.target: You do this by adding your local machines IP address to the firewall exception list.

trans-unit.source: On SQL Databases home page, click SERVERS and then click the server to which you want to connect.
trans-unit.target: On SQL Databases home page, click SERVERS and then click the server to which you want to connect.

trans-unit.source: Click Configure at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click Configure at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: Copy the IP address in CURRENT CLIENT IP ADDRESS.
trans-unit.target: Copy the IP address in CURRENT CLIENT IP ADDRESS.

trans-unit.source: In the Configure page, Allowed IP Addresses includes three boxes where you can specify a rule name and a range of IP addresses as starting and ending values.
trans-unit.target: In the Configure page, Allowed IP Addresses includes three boxes where you can specify a rule name and a range of IP addresses as starting and ending values.

trans-unit.source: For a rule name, you might enter the name of your computer.
trans-unit.target: For a rule name, you might enter the name of your computer.

trans-unit.source: For the start and end range, paste in the IP address of your computer into both boxes, and then click the checkbox that appears.
trans-unit.target: For the start and end range, paste in the IP address of your computer into both boxes, and then click the checkbox that appears.

trans-unit.source: The rule name must be unique.
trans-unit.target: The rule name must be unique.

trans-unit.source: If this is your development computer, you can enter the IP address in both the IP range start box and the IP range end box.
trans-unit.target: If this is your development computer, you can enter the IP address in both the IP range start box and the IP range end box.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, you might need to enter a broader range of IP addresses to accommodate connections from additional computers in your organization.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, you might need to enter a broader range of IP addresses to accommodate connections from additional computers in your organization.

trans-unit.source: Click SAVE at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click SAVE at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: Note: There can be up as much as a five-minute delay for changes to the firewall settings to take effect.
trans-unit.target: Note: There can be up as much as a five-minute delay for changes to the firewall settings to take effect.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to connect to SQL Database using Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to connect to SQL Database using Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: On the taskbar, click Start, point to All Programs, point to Microsoft SQL Server 2014, and then click SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: On the taskbar, click Start, point to All Programs, point to Microsoft SQL Server 2014, and then click SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: In Connect to Server, specify the fully-qualified server name as serverName.database.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: In Connect to Server, specify the fully-qualified server name as serverName.database.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: On Azure, the server name is an autogenerated string composed of alphanumeric characters.
trans-unit.target: On Azure, the server name is an autogenerated string composed of alphanumeric characters.

trans-unit.source: Select SQL Server Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Select SQL Server Authentication.

trans-unit.source: In the Login box, enter the SQL Server administrator login that you specified in the portal when you created your server.
trans-unit.target: In the Login box, enter the SQL Server administrator login that you specified in the portal when you created your server.

trans-unit.source: In the Password box, enter the password that you specified in the portal when you created your server.
trans-unit.target: In the Password box, enter the password that you specified in the portal when you created your server.

trans-unit.source: Click Connect to establish the connection.
trans-unit.target: Click Connect to establish the connection.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server 2014 SSMS with the latest updates offers expanded support for tasks like creating and modifying Azure SQL databases.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server 2014 SSMS with the latest updates offers expanded support for tasks like creating and modifying Azure SQL databases.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you can also use Transact-SQL statements to accomplish these tasks.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you can also use Transact-SQL statements to accomplish these tasks.

trans-unit.source: The steps below provide examples of these statements.
trans-unit.target: The steps below provide examples of these statements.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Transact-SQL with SQL Database, including details about which commands are supported, see <linkText>Transact-SQL Reference (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Transact-SQL with SQL Database, including details about which commands are supported, see <linkText>Transact-SQL Reference (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: While connected to the master database, you can create new databases on the server and modify or drop existing databases.
trans-unit.target: While connected to the master database, you can create new databases on the server and modify or drop existing databases.

trans-unit.source: The steps below describe how to accomplish several common database management tasks through Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: The steps below describe how to accomplish several common database management tasks through Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: To perform these tasks, make sure you are connected to the master database with the server-level principal login that you created when you set up your server.
trans-unit.target: To perform these tasks, make sure you are connected to the master database with the server-level principal login that you created when you set up your server.

trans-unit.source: To open a query window in Management Studio, open the Databases folder, expand the System Databases folder, right-click on master, and then click New Query.
trans-unit.target: To open a query window in Management Studio, open the Databases folder, expand the System Databases folder, right-click on master, and then click New Query.

trans-unit.source: Use the CREATE DATABASE statement to create a new database.
trans-unit.target: Use the CREATE DATABASE statement to create a new database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The statement below creates a new database named myTestDB and specifies that it is a Standard S0 Edition database with a default maximum size of 250GB.
trans-unit.target: The statement below creates a new database named myTestDB and specifies that it is a Standard S0 Edition database with a default maximum size of 250GB.

trans-unit.source: Click Execute to run the query.
trans-unit.target: Click Execute to run the query.

trans-unit.source: Use the ALTER DATABASE statement to modify an existing database, for example if you want to change the name and edition of the database.
trans-unit.target: Use the ALTER DATABASE statement to modify an existing database, for example if you want to change the name and edition of the database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>ALTER DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>ALTER DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The statement below modifies the database you created in the previous step to change edition to Standard S1.
trans-unit.target: The statement below modifies the database you created in the previous step to change edition to Standard S1.

trans-unit.source: Use the DROP DATABASE Statement to delete an existing database.
trans-unit.target: Use the DROP DATABASE Statement to delete an existing database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>DROP DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>DROP DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The statement below deletes the myTestDB database, but don't drop it now because you will use it create logins in the next step.
trans-unit.target: The statement below deletes the myTestDB database, but don't drop it now because you will use it create logins in the next step.

trans-unit.source: The master database has the sys.databases view that you can use to view details about all databases.
trans-unit.target: The master database has the sys.databases view that you can use to view details about all databases.

trans-unit.source: To view all existing databases, execute the following statement:
trans-unit.target: To view all existing databases, execute the following statement:

trans-unit.source: In SQL Database, the USE statement is not supported for switching between databases.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Database, the USE statement is not supported for switching between databases.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you need to establish a connection directly to the target database.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you need to establish a connection directly to the target database.

trans-unit.source: Many of the Transact-SQL statements that create or modify a database must be run within their own batch and cannot be grouped with other Transact-SQL statements.
trans-unit.target: Many of the Transact-SQL statements that create or modify a database must be run within their own batch and cannot be grouped with other Transact-SQL statements.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the statement-specific information available from the links listed above.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the statement-specific information available from the links listed above.

trans-unit.source: The master database keeps track of logins and which logins have permission to create databases or other logins.
trans-unit.target: The master database keeps track of logins and which logins have permission to create databases or other logins.

trans-unit.source: Manage logins by connecting to the master database with the server-level principal login that you created when you set up your server.
trans-unit.target: Manage logins by connecting to the master database with the server-level principal login that you created when you set up your server.

trans-unit.source: You can use the CREATE LOGIN, ALTER LOGIN, or DROP LOGIN statements to execute queries against the master database that will manage logins across the entire server.
trans-unit.target: You can use the CREATE LOGIN, ALTER LOGIN, or DROP LOGIN statements to execute queries against the master database that will manage logins across the entire server.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Managing Databases and Logins in SQL Database</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Managing Databases and Logins in SQL Database</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use the CREATE LOGIN statement to create a new server-level login.
trans-unit.target: Use the CREATE LOGIN statement to create a new server-level login.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE LOGIN (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE LOGIN (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The statement below creates a new login called login1.
trans-unit.target: The statement below creates a new login called login1.

trans-unit.source: Replace password1 with the password of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Replace password1 with the password of your choice.

trans-unit.source: Use the CREATE USER statement to grant database-level permissions.
trans-unit.target: Use the CREATE USER statement to grant database-level permissions.

trans-unit.source: All logins must be created in the master database, but for a login to connect to a different database, you must grant it database-level permissions using the CREATE USER statement on that database.
trans-unit.target: All logins must be created in the master database, but for a login to connect to a different database, you must grant it database-level permissions using the CREATE USER statement on that database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE USER (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE USER (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To give login1 permissions to a database called myTestDB, complete the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To give login1 permissions to a database called myTestDB, complete the following steps:

trans-unit.source: To refresh Object Explorer to view the myTestDB database that you just created, right-click the server name in Object Explorer and then click Refresh.
trans-unit.target: To refresh Object Explorer to view the myTestDB database that you just created, right-click the server name in Object Explorer and then click Refresh.

trans-unit.source: If you closed the connection, you can reconnect by selecting Connect Object Explorer on the File menu.
trans-unit.target: If you closed the connection, you can reconnect by selecting Connect Object Explorer on the File menu.

trans-unit.source: Right-click myTestDB database and select New Query.
trans-unit.target: Right-click myTestDB database and select New Query.

trans-unit.source: Execute the following statement against the myTestDB database to create a database user named login1User that corresponds to the server-level login login1.
trans-unit.target: Execute the following statement against the myTestDB database to create a database user named login1User that corresponds to the server-level login login1.

trans-unit.source: Use the sp\_addrolemember stored procedure to give the user account the appropriate level of permissions on the database.
trans-unit.target: Use the sp\_addrolemember stored procedure to give the user account the appropriate level of permissions on the database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>sp_addrolemember (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>sp_addrolemember (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The statement below gives login1User read-only permissions to the database by adding login1User to the db\_datareader role.
trans-unit.target: The statement below gives login1User read-only permissions to the database by adding login1User to the db\_datareader role.

trans-unit.source: Use the ALTER LOGIN statement to modify an existing login, for example if you want to change the password for the login.
trans-unit.target: Use the ALTER LOGIN statement to modify an existing login, for example if you want to change the password for the login.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>ALTER LOGIN (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>ALTER LOGIN (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The ALTER LOGIN statement should be run against the master database.
trans-unit.target: The ALTER LOGIN statement should be run against the master database.

trans-unit.source: Switch back to the query window that is connected to that database.
trans-unit.target: Switch back to the query window that is connected to that database.

trans-unit.source: The statement below modifies the login1 login to reset the password.
trans-unit.target: The statement below modifies the login1 login to reset the password.

trans-unit.source: Replace newPassword with the password of your choice, and oldPassword with the current password for the login.
trans-unit.target: Replace newPassword with the password of your choice, and oldPassword with the current password for the login.

trans-unit.source: Use the DROP LOGIN statement to delete an existing login.
trans-unit.target: Use the DROP LOGIN statement to delete an existing login.

trans-unit.source: Deleting a login at the server level also deletes any associated database user accounts.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a login at the server level also deletes any associated database user accounts.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>DROP DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>DROP DATABASE (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The DROP LOGIN statement should be run against the master database.
trans-unit.target: The DROP LOGIN statement should be run against the master database.

trans-unit.source: The statement below deletes the login1 login.
trans-unit.target: The statement below deletes the login1 login.

trans-unit.source: The master database has the sys.sql\_logins view that you can use to view logins.
trans-unit.target: The master database has the sys.sql\_logins view that you can use to view logins.

trans-unit.source: To view all existing logins, execute the following statement:
trans-unit.target: To view all existing logins, execute the following statement:

trans-unit.source: SQL Database supports several dynamic management views that you can use to monitor an individual database.
trans-unit.target: SQL Database supports several dynamic management views that you can use to monitor an individual database.

trans-unit.source: Below are a few examples of the type of monitor data you can retrieve through these views.
trans-unit.target: Below are a few examples of the type of monitor data you can retrieve through these views.

trans-unit.source: For complete details and more usage examples, see <linkText>Monitoring SQL Database using Dynamic Management Views</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For complete details and more usage examples, see <linkText>Monitoring SQL Database using Dynamic Management Views</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Querying a dynamic management view requires VIEW DATABASE STATE permissions.
trans-unit.target: Querying a dynamic management view requires VIEW DATABASE STATE permissions.

trans-unit.source: To grant the VIEW DATABASE STATE permission to a specific database user, connect to the database you want to manage with your server-level principle login and execute the following statement against the database:
trans-unit.target: To grant the VIEW DATABASE STATE permission to a specific database user, connect to the database you want to manage with your server-level principle login and execute the following statement against the database:

trans-unit.source: Calculate database size using the sys.dm\_db\_partition\_stats view.
trans-unit.target: Calculate database size using the sys.dm\_db\_partition\_stats view.

trans-unit.source: The sys.dm\_db\_partition\_stats view returns page and row-count information for every partition in the database, which you can use to calculate the database size.
trans-unit.target: The sys.dm\_db\_partition\_stats view returns page and row-count information for every partition in the database, which you can use to calculate the database size.

trans-unit.source: The following query returns the size of your database in megabytes:
trans-unit.target: The following query returns the size of your database in megabytes:

trans-unit.source: Use the sys.dm\_exec\_connections and sys.dm\_exec\_sessions views to retrieve information about current user connections and internal tasks associated with the database.
trans-unit.target: Use the sys.dm\_exec\_connections and sys.dm\_exec\_sessions views to retrieve information about current user connections and internal tasks associated with the database.

trans-unit.source: The following query returns information about the current connection:
trans-unit.target: The following query returns information about the current connection:

trans-unit.source: Use the sys.dm\_exec\_query\_stats view to retrieve aggregate performance statistics for cached query plans.
trans-unit.target: Use the sys.dm\_exec\_query\_stats view to retrieve aggregate performance statistics for cached query plans.

trans-unit.source: The following query returns information about the top five queries ranked by average CPU time.
trans-unit.target: The following query returns information about the top five queries ranked by average CPU time.
